As part of the Greenest City Action Plan, Vancouver aims to be the greenest city in the world by 2020. One way the city plans to achieve this is by reducing its carbon footprint by 33% relative to their 2006 footprint. This app is developed to help users track and reduce their carbon footprint in Vancouver.

A carbon footprint refers to the emission of various carbon compounds as a result from using or producing products. These emissions contribute toward the greenhouse effect and is measured in CO2e (CO2 equivalents). To put Vancouver’s plan in perspective, in 2015, Metro Vancouver’s emissions ranged between 6-8 tonnes CO2e per capita, compared to the global sustainable goal of reaching 2 tonnes CO2e per capita by 2050.

The top two contributing factors for greenhouse gases emissions come from transportation and electricity, both sourcing energy by burning fossil fuel. Other major emission sources include buildings, food, and consumables and waste.
What can be done to reduce emissions?

Instead of driving, people can opt to carpool or take transit to reduce fossil fuel consumption. Switching from gas to electric whether it be in cars or in heating systems can help as well. The carbon emission cost of red meats is significantly higher than white meat, so a change in diet will reduce your footprint.

The reason the two red meats, lamb and beef, have such a high carbon footprint is due to the animals’ ability to expel a lot of methane gas from digestion. The gas byproduct from cows and lambs comprise 85% of all total methane emissions.\nRead more here: https://ec.europa.eu/info/news/eu-agricultural-outlook-european-emissions-linked-agriculture-set-decrease-2030_en

Below is a chart comparing CO2e production cost of various foods. 90% of Vancouverites in the Metro Vancouver area eat foods high in CO2e. Simply by cutting out red meat consumption and replacing it with chicken, as well as reducing total daily meat intake from 35% to 10%, can cut down about 1 million tonnes of CO2e per year.

Our challenge is to have participants install our application and to better understand the impact their diet has on carbon emissions, as well as discover how dietary changes can reduce their carbon footprint.\nIn this app, users track their current meals and their CO2e costs. As they transition to more “green meals”, users can observe how many tonnes of CO2e is reduced in their footprint as well if everyone in their community made the same changes. Users can also share and recommend “low carbon” meals to others in an effort to spread the sustainability movement.
